title: bug: reexport lost fuels::tx::Output under fuels::types::output::Output
body:
We've recently lost our `fuels::tx::Output` reexport of the `fuel_tx::Output`, this PR introduces it back but under a less surprising location (`fuels::types::output::Output` to mimic the already existing `fuels::types::input::Input`)

Although I'm not a fan of the `output::Output` verbosity, I decided to leave it so that it doesn't surprise users. 

We should probably reexport the types under `fuels::types::{Input, Output}` rather than needlessly mention the internal mod structure.

title: refactor!: update `sway` and `fuel-core` to `0.18.1`
body:
The main changes:
- The signing of the transaction and predicate id generation requires `ChainId`(`ConsensusParameters`). 
- Now tokens should be transferred to the contract first, and after you can transfer them via `SMO` or another transfer. So in some tests first we need to transfer money to the contract first.
- Replaced all unsafe code from `fuel-crypto` with safe analog.
- The `produce_blocks` function is updated and doesn't require `TimeParameters`.
- On the `fuel-tx`/`fuel-core` side now, there is a difference in whether the message contains data. If data is empty, it is `MessageCoin` that acts like a `Coin`(has the same rules during execution). If the data field is not empty, then it is a retryable message(or `MessageData`). Messages like this can't be used to pay a transaction fee, and if the execution fails, the message is not consumed(you can use it again in the next transactions). More about them you can read in https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/issues/946. Also, the API changed for resources and not it is `Coins` again. Because of that, some tests now require messages with empty data to be able to spend them.
- Removed redundant usage of `MessageId`. Now the identifier of the message is a `Nonce`.
- Removed `Output::Message`. Now you don't need to specify it in the outputs. Because of that `SMO` opcode doesn't require a message output index anymore. 
- The proof API is updated with a new design: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-core/issues/1046. If you want to prove the block at height `X` you need at least a committed `X + 1` block.

Because some of opcodes were updated the examples require a new `sway`. The corresponding PR: https://github.com/FuelLabs/sway/pull/4525. It creates a cycle of dependencies with this PR.

Closes https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/829 https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/933

BREAKING CHANGES: 
- `Predicate::set_provider` now returns a `Result` because it can fail if the "new" provider has different consensus parameters than the consensus parameters used previously
- `Predicate` can be loaded with a provider by using `load_from_with_provider` and `from_code_and_provider`. The `from_code` and `load_from` remain, and use default `ConsensusParameters` value. This can be discussed further.
- `Provider::new` now takes a `ConsensusParameters` argument, so we can avoid changing the API of downstream clients. 
- `setup_test_client` now returns `ConsensusParameters` of the client. This was either this or `setup_test_provider` would have to change, and the former is much less used than the latter.

title: chore: update `sway` to `0.38.0` and `fuel-core` to `0.17.11`
body:
Bumping the sway to `0.38.0` and `fuel-core` to `0.17.11`. Updated contracts according to new breaching changes.

It is preparation for the `fuel-core 0.18.0`. I extracted it into a separate change not to mix breaking changes from the `fuel-core` with breaking changes from the `sway`.

title: style: fix typo in function names
chore: default-features warnings on cargo nightly
body:
closes: #918 

From [the cargo book](https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/specifying-dependencies.html):
> Other than optional and features, inherited dependencies cannot use any other dependency key (such as version or default-features).

We've been inheriting workspace deps and then trying to disable default features. Cargo doesn't support this. If a dep has default features enabled when defined at the workspace level, those features are there to stay. You can only add more to them via `features` or make the dep itself optional in the place you're using it via `optional=true`.

The check for this still hasn't landed in cargo stable. I opted not to add a CI step to build `fuels-rs` with the nightly toolchain to check for regressions in this regard.

Functionally nothing has changed. The changes are primarily so we don't mislead ourselves and so we don't run into an error when this does reach stable.

}

body:
Closes #914

This PR moves receipt decoding to the new `ReceiptParser`. The key difference is that the `ReceiptParser` owns a copy of the receipts and will consume an entry when a value is generated. 

I've also found that `test_contract_raw_slice` is duplicated so I removed one instance of it.

title: refactor!: `fuels` wasm-offending packages/reexports hidden behind `std` flag
body:
closes: #912 

Read the issue for context. Only implementation notes to follow.

### Breaking changes
* `Abigen` code will now refer to types through the `fuels` package since it is now wasm compatible. @deekerno @ra0x3 the indexer should now just include `fuels` as a dependency taking care to disable the default features (since `std` is the default). You can access `fuels_core` stuff through `fuels::core`; `fuels_types` through `fuels::types`; `fuels_macros` through `fuels::macros`. 

The hotfix is still in place -- mostly to make the Abigen code-writing experience more enjoyable. If we remove it completely then we'd have to do a `no_std` check whenever we use a Vec, `format!`, `String` etc. 

This way we always write `::std::vec::Vec` and leave the rest to the (now smaller) wasm hotfix.

As we become more wasm compatible the rest of the `fuels-*` crates will become exposed through `fuels` reexports.

title: bug: storage slots have to be sorted in a create tx
body:
closes: #908 

I've placed the sorting inside `set_storage_slots` in our `CreateTransactionBuilder` because that is the last stop before the storage slots are frozen inside a `fuel_tx::Transaction`.

This covers storage slots that came either from the merging process described in the issue or were manually provided to the tx builder.

Besides being used in a create tx, storage slots are also a part of the state root calculation. Storage slot order is unimportant here because they are being inserted into a Merkel tree.

title: feat!: support scripts and predicates in `setup_program_test!` (old `setup_contract_test`)
body:
closes: #909 
co-developed with: @hal3e 

You can now generate bindings for scripts and predicates via the boilerplate-reduction-helper `setup_program_test` (formerly `setup_contract_test`). You can also create a script instance via `LoadScript`. Example:
```rust
    setup_program_test!(
        Wallets("wallet"),
        Abigen(Script(
            name = "MyScript",
            project = "packages/fuels/tests/types/scripts/script_generics"
        )),
        LoadScript(
            name = "script_instance",
            script = "MyScript",
            wallet = "wallet"
        )
    );
```

 We decided against doing `LoadPredicate` because predicates have to undergo further tweaking after being created. We felt it was best that we leave the whole process visible.
 
 The PR isn't that big but GitHub didn't detect files being moved around.
 
###  Breaking changes:
* Name was changed from `setup_contract_test` into `setup_program_test`
* Command for generating bindings (`Abigen`) now requires the program type to be stated. Before: `Abigen(name="...`, now: `Abigen(Contract(name="..."` etc.

title: refactor!: separate `Contract` loading and deploying
body:
closes: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/892

__Updated PR description__

After taking in consideration all comments made in this PR, I have decided to do a bit more refactoring on `Contract`. I have tried to move functions not related directly to `Contract` to places where they make more sense. I have:
- Moved `contract_deployment_transaction` to `CreateTransactionBuilder::prepare_contract_deployment`
- Moved `get_storage_slots` and its logic to `StorageConfiguration` - No need for `Contract` to handle this
- Moved `validate_path_and_extension` outside as it is now also used by `StorageConfiguration`
- Moved `method_hash` and `should_compute_custom_input_offset` - No need for `Contract` to handle this
- Deleted `deploy` and renamed `deploy_loaded` to `deploy` - big breaking change will elaborate below
Other refactors:
- Made `DeployConfiguration` into `LoadConfiguration` and took out `TxParametres`
  - The idea is to separate loading and deploying of the contracts. Now the user will add the `TxParameters` when he actually deploy the contract

The biggest change for the user is the way to deploy contracts. Previously the user would use `deploy` directly: 

```rust
     let contract_id = Contract::deploy(
        "tests/contracts/configurables/out/debug/configurables.bin",
        &wallet,
        DeployConfiguration::default(),
    )
    .await?;
```
This function basically did two things: Load and then deploy the contract. I propose we use this instead:

```rust
    let contract_id = Contract::load_from(
        "tests/contracts/configurables/out/debug/configurables.bin",
        LoadConfiguration::default(),
    )?
    .deploy(&wallet, TxParameters::default())
    .await?;
```

This makes it clear what is being done. Makes the `LoadConfiguration` simpler and also now the user can get the `contract_id` or `state_root` easily.

```rust
    let contract_id = Contract::load_from(
        "tests/contracts/configurables/out/debug/configurables.bin",
        LoadConfiguration::default(),
    )?
    .contract_id();
```

For reference this is what the user had to do previously to get the `contract_id`

```rust
    let compiled_contract = Contract::load_contract(
        contract_binary_path,
        DeployConfiguration::default(),
    )?;
    let (test_contract_id, _) = Contract::compute_contract_id_and_state_root(&compiled_contract);
```
thanks @segfault-magnet for your suggestions and helping me move code around :smile: 

### Checklist

title: chore: reorganize harness tests
body:
closes: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/896

In this PR, I propose a new harness tests layout for types. The main idea is to separate types tests based on the program. Initially, we agreed on `contracts` and `scripts` but I have also separated `predicates`. This is the new structure:

```shell
tests
...
│
├── types/
│  ├── contracts/
│  │  ├── b512/
│  │  ...
│  │  ├── vector_output/
│  │  └── vectors/
│  ├── predicates/
│  │  ├── address/
│  │  ...
│  │  ├── structs/
│  │  └── u64/
│  └── scripts/
│     ├── options_results/
│     │  ...
│     └── script_vectors/
 ...
├── types_contracts.rs
├── types_predicates.rs
└── types_scripts.rs
...
```
Changes:
- `types` folder has 3 sub-folder for each program
- `types.rs` was split into three files `types_contracts.rs`, `types_predicates.rs` and `types_scripts.rs`
- Removed program name from sway projects where they were not needed. E.g.  `contract_storage_test` -> `storage`
- Deleted duplicated test: `type_safe_output_values`
- Deleted unused sway projects: `require_contract_abi` and `require_from_contract` and `script_vector`

title: fix: coins query no longer returns spent coins
body:

- [x] I have done my best to ensure that my PR adheres to [the Fuel Labs Code Review Standards](https://github.com/FuelLabs/rfcs/blob/master/text/code-standards/external-contributors.md).
- [x] I have requested a review from the relevant team or maintainers.

title: feat: type path support (`forc` flag `--json-abi-with-callpaths`)
body:
closes: #791 

Type paths are currently feature-gated behind the `forc` flag `--json-abi-with-callpaths`. Docs were updated to guide those affected by #791 to build their contracts with the flag above.

The SDK remains compatible with programs compiled with or without the flag. The CI is updated to protect against regressions in this regard. Once this becomes the default in `forc` the backward compatibility will be dropped.

Shared types handling was updated to be less confusing to the user. Shared types are still generated inside `shared_types` but are now reexported to each place where they were originally taken from.

 I.e. types will be shared transparently. If a naming collision happens the user doesn't need to think whether the type was shared but rather just use the original path of the type.

title: feat: check for unused md files in docs
body:
closes: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/767

I have extended our `check-docs` script which now checks for unused `md` files in `docs/src`.

>Note: The file `docs/src/cookbook/modify-contract-call-tx.md` is not used! We have to decide what to do with it.

`try_from_type_application` will not panic anymore. Instead we propagate an `InvalidData` error.

Breaking changes:
`Type::from()` is now `Type::try_from()`.

title: refactor: contract deployment configuration
Resolve cyclic deps
body:
Closes #808

This PR untangles the cyclic dependency between `fuels-signers`, `fuels-core` and `fuels-test-helpers` by relocating some wallet tests to `fuels` and removing the use of test helpers where they're not relevant for the test itself.

title: fix: latest release cannot be used by cargo
body:
If you run 
```bash
 CARGO_LOG=debug cargo update  
```
On a simple project that has `fuels = "0.37.0"` as a dep, among a bunch of other logs you'll see the following:
```
[2023-02-23T15:38:57Z INFO  cargo::sources::registry::index] failed to parse "fu/el/fuels-programs" registry package: feature `std` includes `fuels-test-helpers/std`, but `fuels-test-helpers` is not a dependency
[2023-02-23T15:38:57Z DEBUG cargo::core::registry] load/precise  registry `crates-io`
[2023-02-23T15:38:57Z DEBUG cargo::sources::registry::index] cache missing for "fu/el/fuels-signers" error: No such file or directory (os error 2)
[2023-02-23T15:38:57Z DEBUG cargo::sources::registry::index] slow path for "fu/el/fuels-signers"
[2023-02-23T15:38:57Z INFO  cargo::sources::registry::index] failed to parse "fu/el/fuels-signers" registry package: feature `std` includes `fuels-test-helpers/std`, but `fuels-test-helpers` is not a dependency
[2023-02-23T15:38:57Z DEBUG cargo::core::registry] load/precise  registry `crates-io`
```
`fuels-signers` and `fuels-programs` are the only ones being complained about and they're exactly the ones that don't have a matching version. 

It would seem that enabling features on `dev-dependencies` via a traditional feature is not something you should do.

It will pass on your local machine, it will pass our CI. 

You'll only find out when you release it and stop having the dev dependencies.

we should look into guarding against this if this ends up the reason behind the release issue.

title: fix: ci individual package testing
body:
closes: #851

Passing `--workspace` will make cargo test each package individually. It is not exactly the same effect as going into the package and running `cargo test` due to workspace-wide feature unification happening before the test.

This is as close as we can get without bumping our CI times (probably) significantly by running `cargo test` for each package and then for the workspace as a whole.

title: feat: support returning `Vec<>` types from contracts
body:
This PR closes #746 by allowing the user to return a vector containing any type
from a smart contract.  
It relies on one main change:
* The script that uses the `CALL` opcode on the contract now needs the output
  type of the contract call to work properly. Indeed, to know how many bytes
  the vector takes in VM memory and return all these bytes, you need to know
  the encoding width of the inner type of the vector.

Closes #845

Extends `estimate_tx_dependancies` to also add output messages if they're missing.

closes: #842 

Fuel-core probably uses HOME for the database path, so clearing all environment variables would cause problems for that use case. 

But since we use the in memory database, everything works even without the environment.

title: fix: Fuel-Core breaking changes
body:
Fixes the fuel-core issue. 

A bad CLI default introduced in `fuel-core` broke the 'with-binary' build of the SDK. 

The fact that spawning fuel-core as a library now implements RAII, where dropping the handle kills the node broke the 'with-fuel-core-as-library' build.

title: fix!: wasm compatibility for `fuels-types`
body:
closes: #837 
closes: #854

A big thank you to @hal3e for help with the CI. 

The wasm offending functionality is now hidden behind the feature `std` in `fuels-types` and in `fuels-core` as well. 

### Breakage:
@digorithm 
It is part of the crate's default features, so most users shouldn't feel the change -- especially since there weren't other other features that would have made somebody do `default-features = false` in their `Cargo.toml`. 

But if they did for whatever reason, then they might see parts of `fuels-types` disappear since the `std` feature would not be enabled. So that makes it a theoretically breaking change.

Also `fuels` had two feature flags: `fuel-core` and `fuel-core-lib`. `fuel-core` is removed since it was implicitly added because the optional dependency `fuel-core` had not been referred to by prepending `dep:` to it.

`fuel-core` used to enable the fuel-core-lib only partially and was not the right flag to use.

### About the implementation
Cargo features should be additive by design. This means that you cannot remove dependencies by adding features. 

This further means that wasm support is generally implemented by *hiding* wasm-offending code behind a feature (such as `std`). 

In our case, if we want to be WASM compatible, we must not enable the `std` feature on any `fuels-*` crates our project might depend on.

Feature unification makes this a bit difficult. If there is even one dependency that enabled `std` on some `fuels-*` crate, all other crates that are part of that compilation will also have the `std` feature enabled for that crate.

Because of this, I've made it default for our workspace dependencies to start off without defaults (and thus without the `std` flag). 

If any of our crates need it, they will have to enable the feature explicitly.

title: Update for `fuel-asm` refactor. Updates for fuel-core 0.17, fuel-vm 0.26.
body:
This updates all crates for the `fuel-asm` refactor introduced here: FuelLabs/fuel-vm#283. You can learn more about the change at this PR. The aim is to propagate this last API-breaking update through fuels-rs and sway before beta-3.

The associated fuel-core PR can be found here: FuelLabs/fuel-core#973.

Once the refactor lands upstream and the [patch] table is removed in this PR, this unblocks the associated sway update PR here: FuelLabs/sway#4004.

title: fix wasm compatibility when `no_std` is used in Abigen
body:
fixes: #822

My thanks to @Br1ght0ne for his help around wasm. Please check if this makes sense :D 

To be considered a hotfix in order to unblock the indexer team. I will restructure/clean it asap. 

Even though you can use parts of the rust stdlib in wasm, I've still decided to add `#![no_std]` to the wasm test. This at least catches any usage of `std::` in the expanded code. If we ever find ourselves using subsets of the std that are compatible with wasm but not available in `core` or `alloc` then we'll figure out how to write a better test.

The `fuels` dependency has been removed from the wasm test, so the passing of the test proves we're not referencing `fuels` anymore. 

The derive macros of `Tokenizable`, `Parameterize` and `TryInto` had to receive two new attributes: `FuelsCorePath` and `NoStd`. 

The first one is so that we don't use `fuels` when expanding the derive macro in wasm builds.

The second one communicates that the derive macro should generate wasm-compatible code. It might also be done using conditional compilation but then we would need to agree on the condition, i.e. do we add a feature flag `wasm`, do we use the built-in one `no_std`, etc. 

From now on, to ease the pain later, we should first see if something is available in `core` before referencing it from std when modifying Abigen. But more on that after the refactor.

body: add error handling section for the Call response page in the docs

title: feat: Reintroduce `Abigen` publicly in a new crate `fuels-code-gen`
body:
Moving `Abigen` from `fuels-core` into `fuels-macro` and making it private broke the indexer which relied on `Abigen` due to issues of using `abigen!` inside other macros.

`Abigen` could not have been exported from `fuels-macro` since it is a `proc-macro` crate type that cannot export anything except proc macros.

The only solution was to create a new crate.

title: feat!: enable payments with predicates
body:
The PR aims to enable predicates to be used as wallets, allowing payments and transactions to be made with them. The first step taken in this direction was to modify the `predicate_bindings` function so that it returns the `Predicate` data type, which will be further used as we use the wallet.

```rust
MyPredicateHandler::load_from(
"../../packages/fuels/tests/predicates/predicate_signatures/out/debug/predicate_signatures.bin",
).set_data(signatures).get_predicate();
```
This code loads the predicate .bin together with the signature for unlocking the predicate and returns the `Predicate` data type, which can be used as a wallet for making transactions, etc.

In addition, I added a new public trait called `Account`, which includes a group of functions common to both wallets and predicates. Any function that receives `T: Account` as a parameter can use these common functions.

```rust
pub trait Account: std::fmt::Debug + Send + Sync { ... }
```

Predicates that have dynamic data as input require special handling because the underlying pointer needs to be adjusted with the right offset for the actual data. To resolve the pointers of a given predicate input, we need to know all the previous tx inputs. The problem here is that the transaction can be modified at any point which can potentially invalidate the offsets.

`fuels_types::Input` is introduced to circumvent this. For predicates, it stores the relevant resource and the predicate data as `UnresolvedBytes`.

Some of `ScriptTransaction`s methods have been moved to the new `ScriptTransactionBuilder`. The idea is that the builder works on our input types and still allows for modifications. Once `build()` is called, the predicate data is resolved for all predicate inputs and the resulting `ScriptTransaction` doesn't allow for further changes to the inputs.

Some caveats:
- We currently don't have a native `Output` type. Should we implement as a thin wrapper for the sake of consistency?
- `UnresolvedBytes` has been moved to fuels_types to avoid cyclic deps. This also means that `Data` moved with it. Since 
   `Data` is used for parts of the abigen, we had to make it public. Is there a better alternative?
- To deduplicate significant amounts of code, `get_asset_inputs_for_amount` accepts `witness_index` as a parameter. For predicates we just ignore it in the implementation but overall it doesn't make sense in the context of predicates.
 
closes #809

title: Fuel Core v0.16.1
body:
###### Description of changes

Update `fuels-rs` to the latest `fuel-core 0.16.1` and latest `sway 0.34.0`.

Due to changes in `fuel-asm` for GTF, this is causing yet another circular upgrade issue.
- Used `{ workspace = true }` syntax to use one version across the project and simplify integration with new changes in the future.
- Added `ci_checks.sh` script to compile all tests to simplify integration of changes like this in the future.
- Update contracts to be compatible with `sway 0.34.0`.
- Updated tests to be compatible with `fuel-core 0.16.1`.

related PR: https://github.com/FuelLabs/sway/pull/3961

title: feat: add support for assert_eq logs
body:
closes: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/799

The SDK now supports decoding logs from an `assert_eq` revert. In Sway, `assert_eq(a,b)` will log both `a` and `b` and then revert with a specific `revert_id`. Previously, we only had logs from `require` reverts but now we have to check the `revert_id` and see what kind of revert it is. 

I have:
- Turned `RevertTransactionError` to a struct that now also hold the specific `revert_id`. 
- Refactored error generation in `ExecutableFuelCall` when using `simulate`. Now we will get a reason if the simulation fails.
- Refactored the log decoding code and separated it into two cases: `require` and `assert_eq`.
- Added `LogId` tuple struct
- Moved `log_type_lookup` to `fuels_programs::logs` from `fuels_core::utils`
- Refactored `TransactionStatus::Failure` handling in `provider.rs` so that we can get the specific `revert_id`
- Added `assert_eq` tests for both `contract` and `script`

>***Note:*** the PR is blocked by: https://github.com/FuelLabs/sway/issues/3946 and a new `forc` release. However, I have manually created logs with the appropriate revert so that we can work on the SDK side while they fix the bug. Hopefully when the bug is fixed,  I will just have to change the sway code.

title: fix: sign transaction in `ScriptCallHandler`
body: This PR should fix signing inside of the `ScriptCallHandler` https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/810

- Add README FAQ instructions for how to run the docs locally

title: feat!: `derive`able `Parameterize` and `Tokenizable`
body:
closes: https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/785 - co-developed with @segfault-magnet 

If all your `fields`/`variants` of your custom `struct`/`enum` implement `Parameterizable` and `Tokenizable` you can derive the two traits using the new macros. Here is an example: 

```rust
#[derive(Parameterize, Tokenizable)]
struct MyStruct2<T: Tokenizable + Parameterize> {
    a: T,
}

#[derive(Parameterize, Tokenizable)]
pub struct MyStruct<T: Tokenizable + Parameterize> {
    field1: u64,
    field3: Address,
    field2: Option<MyStruct2<T>>,
}
```

If you do not have `fuels` as a dependency you will have to specify the full path to the `fuels_types` crate. Here is an example of how we used the derive macro inside `fuels_types`:
```rust
#[derive(Debug, PartialEq, Eq, Copy, Clone, Parameterize, Tokenizable)]
#[FuelsTypesPath("crate")]
pub struct B512 {
    pub bytes: [Bits256; 2],
}
```

Breaking changes:
- Moved `Parameterize` and `Tokenizable` traits from `fuels_core::traits` to `fuels_types::traits`
- Unit `enum` variants no longer have parentheses i.e.  before `SomeEnum::A()` now `SomeEnum::A`
- `EvmAddress` - field `value` is not public anymore. We derived both `Parametrize` and `Tokenizable` using the derive macro. The method `from_token` will not clear the first  12 bytes anymore. The reasoning is that: Tokens coming from Sway will always have the first 12 bytes cleared. Tokens from a manually created `EvmAddress` will always have the first twelve bytes cleared.

title: Improve devx for extracting data from Script
Methods without #[payable] cannot accept assets
body:
Closes https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/742

.call_params() now returns a Result which either resolves to the ContractCallHandler instance or an InvalidCallParameters error. The latter happens when the user tries to set call parameters with an amount > 0 on a contract method that isn't payable.

title: cargo doc warnings to become errors in our CI
body:
I have added a new step to our CI pipeline to check for broken_intra_doc_links in our documentation. If any warnings are found, the CI will fail.

```rust
name: Check Docs. Warnings
      run: | 
        ! cargo doc |& grep -q "broken_intra_doc_links"
```

closes #766

title: docs: update node-beta-1 to node-beta-2
body:
Update the `Connecting to the Testnet or an external node` section to refer to beta-2 instead of beta-1

closes #773

title: refactor: fuels-types Error
body:
Because of the refactoring we have done in the SDK, some error types defined in `fuels_types::Error` are not needed anymore. In this PR I have tried to remove the unnecessary error variants and I have introducing an `error!` macro (thanks @segfault-magnet for the macro implementation)

More specifically, I have:
- removed `anyhow` completely from the SDK.
  - We had a `From` implementation that turned any `anyhow` error to `ParseTokenStreamError` which was wrong.
- removed the `CodecError`
- removed Error variants:
  - `ParseIntError`
  - `ParseBoolError`
  - `ParseHexError`
  - `ParseTokenStreamError`
  - `CompilationError`
- added `Result` type alias `Result<T> = std::result::Result<T, Error>` 

Added the `error!` macro. This macro makes it easier to write the error manually. Prevously we had to do something like this:
```rust
Err(Error::InstantiationError(format!(
       "Expected `bool`, got {:?}",
       other
))),
```
now we can write:
```rust
Err(error!(InstantiationError,
       "Expected `bool`, got {:?}",
       other
)),
```
In addition, we can pass a string literal to the macro i.e. we do not have to use `.into()` or `to_string()` to turn it into a `String`.
This macro can only be used with errors that have a `String` field. Those are the errors that we manually make.
IMO the macro makes the error instantiation cleaner. If the team does not like it we can remove it :smile:

title: fix: add both chain_config and coins to node config
refactor: implement forc/sway workspaces to build fuels e2e tests
body:
### Changes Made
- Added a file `packages/fuels/Forc.toml` that defines a `[workspace]` containing the paths to all integration tests.
- All new tests should be added to this file.
- The `test-projects` script has been deleted as it is no longer needed.

### Question
Should a script be created to automate the process of adding tests to `Forc.toml`?

### How to Build Tests
To build the integration tests, go to the `packages/fuels` folder and run the `force build` command, or `forc build --path packages/fuels`. Other commands offered by `forc` can also be used in the same way.


closes #768

title: refactor!: move abigen to fuels-macros crate
body:
This PR is related to https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuels-rs/issues/785

The new `derive` macros will be implemented in the `fuels-macros` package, formerly `fuels-abigen-macro`.

To use the  `derive` macros in `fuels-types` we need to import `fuels-macros` there. However, this will create a dependency cycle:

`fuels-types` <- `fuels-core` <- `fuels-macros` <- `fuels-types` ...

@segfault-magnet and I agreed that the natural place to break the cycle is `fuels-core` <- `fuels-macros`. This dependency is mainly due to the `Abigen` code being in `fuels-core`. We do not see a need to have the code generation in `fuels-core` so we have moved it to the `fuels-macros`, where we have the rest of the code generation.

Breaking change:
- `Abigen` is not public anymore - if there should come a time when `Abigen` needs to be public we can discuss alternatives like creating a new crate.

<s>P.S. GitHub bugged out on the line numbers... we did not delete 1500 lines :smile: </s>
The deleted lines come from `functions_gen.rs` which should have been deleted by the big PR but made it through. It wasn't part of the compilation, just hanging there.

Also, the tokenizer is now dead, since it was only used by the cli tool, and we still haven't decided on what to do with it.

title: Remove --no-verify flag
body: The `--no-verify` flag skips the sorting step of the github action we use to publish our crates. This might be causing some publishing issues right now. I'm removing it to experiment whether or not this fixes the publishing issue.

title: feat: improve contract deployment error messages

```
is

```
